												A disgustingly bad business model on an otherwise fantastic game..**UPDATE!!** I just wanted to say that I recently gave the game another go and apparently they've added a free rotation to what kinds of animals you can hunt, kind of like different FTP games like League of Legends have a free character rotation that cycles week to week on what you're allowed to use, or in this case hunt. THIS IS A STEP IN THE RIGHT DIRECTION! It certainly does not turn the game completely around, but it's a start. I'll give credit where credit is due, but the problems that were always there still remain. The problem with this free rotation is that.. if your basic free ammo or gun can't hunt that specie.. then it's pretty much useless to you. You still have to buy the correct gun and the correct ammo to be allowed to hunt it. I'm not going to change any of my review beyond this part here, as I believe it's important to maintain records like this. Some info may be slightly out of date, however. Just keep that in mind.OLD REVIEW:It's such a shame when you come across a fantastic game that's ruined by one of the worst payment models in any game you've ever seen. TheHunter is one of those games. What can you do for free, you ask? Well, you can hunt Mule Deer. That's it. That's all you can do. Shoot Mule Deer with one gun, one type of ammo. The default stuff you start with is all you get. It says you can also hunt Cottontail Rabbits, ah but the catch is you need to buy the correct gun to use in order to be allowed to hunt it. So, Rabbits aren't even free either.Can you earn enough to eventually buy another gun? Only one other gun is available for purchase using the game's earned currency (called gm$). Every other gun must be bought using real world money (called em$). And that's not all.Want the privilege to be able to hunt something else? You need to buy licenses. Doesn't sound so bad, does it? Well, they come in 1 day, 7 day, and 28 day variants. Yup, that's right. They expire. So you have to buy them multiple times to continue hunting what you want. Buy a 1 day license but then get called in to work? Congrats! You've just wasted your money! You CAN buy these with gm$, but the costs are so high that you'll be farming Mule Deer for weeks in order to finally be able to experience something else.Oh but hold on. It's not like each kill you make earns you gm$. Hah! You wish! Nope. The only way to earn gm$ is to complete "missions" which range from tracking certain animals, spotting certain animals, and harvesting certain animals, among other similar tasks. Doesn't sound so bad, does it? Well, they typically reward only 100 gm$ for each mission, and your shotgun costs 6300 gm$, a typical 1 day license costs anywhere between 1800 - 2400 gm$. For ONE DAY, for ONE SPECIE. Let that sink in.Would I recommend this game? Based on its business model at the time of writing? NO WAY. Stay FAR away from this cash-grab game, unless you enjoy having them grab at your pockets the moment you try their game.Also, NEVER EVER EVER DO ANY OF THE 3RD PARTY STUFF THEY ASK YOU TO DO. You can do things like surveys, downloads, watch videos, etc. to earn some em$ (that's right, paid currency). But most of these third party "offers" infect your computer with all sorts of malware, and most of them don't end up forking over the em$ at the end. You'll be turned away from most surveys because you "aren't the target consumer". For instance, when I answered that I was a white male on a survey, I was immediately declined and turned away, reward not given.If the payment model is improved? I would recommend this game in a heartbeat. It's fun to play, all the shady practices considered. I just wish they had gone about their payment model better than this garbage. Oh well, someone else will come along and do it right eventually.

												Hello everybody,I play this game since nearly the beginning, have seen the initial developer go bankrupt and the new developer take over. I have seen month with nothing happening in terms of developments and I have seen the last few month after multiplayer was released with new stuff released every few weeks.If you love hunting simulations, theHunter for sure is the game you want. It's way more realistic then Cabela's games, it has pretty nice graphics and huge different hunting locations with many, many animals to hunt. Every species feels special and there has not been a really good hunting simulation since Deer Hunter 2005.- Pricing - The downside: You need to invest a whole lot of money. To really enjoy the game you need a membership for about 5$ a month. No membership and you can only hunt very few species, need to buy ammo for all but the default rifle and can't create multiplayer games. Sure you can stick with some basic guns, but to take part in competitions and finish missions you need a whole lot of different guns. Each between 3 and 5$. Not to forget, there are tree stands, ground blinds and tents you would like to use sooner or later because there are very few fixed hunting towers on the maps and... yes, each of these items is another 4,50$ from your wallet.Just a few numbers for you:All weapons with scopes (not caluclation different skins or "premium" skins)more then 150$All callers (no decoys, no consumables like scents):about 20$Decoys for one full area for each species:about 30$Clothing depends on what you want, so I don't add a number to this, but each clothing set is about 5$... and you guess it: Some work better in different areas or against different species.Stands and tents... lets say two of each for each reserve, you place them permanently, you don't want to pick them up after each hunt, so you can't really use the same two everywhere.more then 200$Sure, you are free to choose if you want this items, but to get everything out of the game you want this stuff. And more, every few weeks there is a new weapon, new cool cloth and your membership runs out every now and then. - Earn ingame money -There are ways to earn ingame money: Win competitions, but without spending money you can only take part in very few competitions and so the chance is low (and the prize money gets you nowhere). The developers also have partnered with third-party pages who offer you some money for playing other online games, taking part in surveys or downloading and using different applications. The results are spam on your email address, malware and a lot of these offers simply don't reward you.There is a different ingame currency you earn completing missions, but you can only use this "money" on consumables and you need a good bunch of weapons to finish most missions, so again: No way without spending money. There is no way to grind the gear inside the game.Without spending money you stick with the .243 for the free Mule Deer and you can unlock the Single Shot Shotgun to hunt Cottontail Rabbits, but you need to buy the ammo for it. That works with earned money for some time, but sooner or later you will run out of missions to do without buying weapons or a membership for real money.- Bugs -The game is full of bugs. I personally can't say there are gamebreakers, but animals getting stuck in trees, climbing trees, nearly all weapons stuck into your arm and broken reloading animations and other smaller and bigger bugs are around since a long time and often they return after a few patches. Gamebreaking bugs get fixed pretty fast but smaller bugs are often not relevant enough (and the fixes can't be sold like new weapons or cloth) so we will for sure see this bugs for some more time.- Community -Just have to add it now, after multiple insults from fanboys. This game has a small die hard community that are happy to have this game, due it's the only one of it's kind. This makes them accept and defend every action the developers take. Since this review I often got friend requests from some of these guys that have nothing better to do then to tell me I'm a hypocrit to play this game a lot and not remommending it in my review. That's what you get from the community if you are not a 100% fan and don't think it's okay to pay a small fortune for this game.- Conclusion -As said, I'm into this game since years, I love it and I will keep playing it, but since about a year this game is all about money and everything ingame is pretty expensive. Like with this the pre-release review postet on Steam, my personal experience showed me, that the developers break promises and contracts, lie in some cases, solve things always to their best and only communicate public what makes them look good.- Tipp for beginners -If you enjoyed the small free part, go to {LINK REMOVED}bit.ly/1oEMUr0 or google for "theHunter 2014 box" and purchase a key from the boxed edition of the game. For about 17 € you get 6 month membership (hunt all species, get free ammo for all guns) some starter weapons that allow you to hunt all species ethically and some additional gear. It's the best deal you can currently get as a beginner. This box is also available at Amazon and some other retailers if you want the box itself.- Update after some actions taken -Today the developers release a new .22 handgun and to make the game more realistic, changed the existing and wide spread .357 handgun and made it unethical for some species. What might be realistic is clearly forcing players to buy the new gun for about 4$.Changing already sold virtual items might be common but this change make this weapon pretty useless. Why? Because a lot of players have it. It's not a good weapon against larger animals and was pretty often used against birds, now the only animals it's good for are fox and coyote.The new reserve released some time ago included the new "feature" of climbing walls... what simply is a bad mini game and asks you to buy a new consumable: Climbing gear. Some would argue that it's purchaseable with gm$ and you can take 75% back if you remove it, but it's again something that will eat up the earned gm$ from free players and make this game harder to play for free (besides, it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mechanic that has nothing to do with hunting).

It's unacceptable to make me pay money to access that much content in a free to play game.It costs nothing to download, but I feel entitled to a refund.First of all, there was no tutorial for this. I was just thrown in, and expected to know how to hunt. I wandered aimlessly for a while, until I found some tracks. I followed them, and found some more tracks and some scat. Then a message popped up: "You don't have the required license to hunt whitetail deer". What? I just spent almost forty real minutes tracking this thing down, only to not be allowed to shoot it. This is a video game! I shouldn't need to buy licenses to hunt animals! And, since this was my first time playing, wouldn't it be nice to give me some licenses for free, so I can get a feel for the game before investing money in it (it's free to play, so I shouldn't have to pay to play it)! I do not have a gun, hunting equipment, or hunting licenses. I played this so I could hunt. After playing this, I might as well just get all of those things, because it would be something I could make memories out of, actually go outside, and do with my friends.Valve, I am begging you, set standards for what can and cannot be free to play. 												YES....and.....NO!After playing this game for an unhealthy amount of time both on Steam and before it was released on that platform, it is probably time for a little review of this game that I love to hate and hate that I love. First and foremost: calling this game a "Free-to-Play" is like calling Donald Trump "Mr. President". They are both technically true but just seems like stretching reality a bit too much. Though it has to be stated that it has become more "Free-to-Play" than it used to be. Once there was a time where you could hunt one animal at one map/reserve with one weapon and be left with overwhelmingly many messages about all you are not allowed to do, what you can't shoot and where you can't go. At the time of this review you now have a couple of animals you can hunt for free with a couple of guns and even a couple more animals on rotation every week. Still you will not have a great experience with this game if you have no interest in putting any money into it. And that is what it boils down to....For hunter enthusiasts and others that are looking for a mostly realistic hunting simulator with a lot of variation, weapons to use, scenery to explore, competitions to enter and have a lot of free time on your hand, this would probably be the best thing you can find out there today. It becomes even better if you put in some extra money to buy additional equipment to make your hunting experience even richer. But you need to know in advance that it will cost you. There's a yearly subscription (can also get 3 months and 6 months) and tons of  weapons and equipment you can (and probably need to) buy. It uses an in-game currency, which you can get by winning competitions (for most animals every day in 3 levels of experience). Seems like a lot of chances to win right? Not so much. It is not often you get that winning animal, and it is not much you win for each competition, so it will take a long time to save up for useful equipment. If you really get into this game, expect to open that wallet to get stuff faster.That being said, I rarely feel ripped off with what I have put into this game. Sure, I feel that for what you get of updates and new things in the game you don't really get enough for that yearly subscription. Any new added weapons and equipment is not included in this subscription and has to be paid for seperately.  Expect to get one new reserve and a handful of new animals to hunt, plus up to three hunting towers included for free a year. It has to be said that of the vast amount of equipment and weapons are optional and very few affect your chances of placing higher in the competitions, but rather make it more convenient when hunting. I.E. buying and placing tents gives you more places on the map to spawn, other items makes it easier to get in closer to the animals, like blinds and tree stands, while you can also buy camping equipment (consumable) to fast travel between spawn points. Next to the joy of just hunting pixelated animals that behaves relatively realistically and animates well and joining competitions there is a rather large set of missions to complete based on specific animals, specific maps or specific weapons. Unfortunately to complete all these you will have to buy a lot of the weapons and equipment as they are simply needed in certain levels of the missions (Like "shoot two Cotttontail Rabbits with a longbow from a tree stand"). Completing missions earns you a secondary currency which can be used to buy certain items (mostly consumable ones).There is also ethics to consider. You can't just run around shooting any animal you see with whatever weapon you have at hand. Specific animals have to be shot with a proper weapon and with proper ammo. You can't shoot a rabbit with a shotgun with slugs or shoot a grizzly with a .223 bolt action. Each weapon lists what animals it can be used for and you don't really need many to cover them all. If you buy one of the Starter Bundle Subscriptions you get a selection of weapons and equipment.There are also achievements to be earned in the game. They are not of the most creative part and mostly contain harvesting  a set amount of a specific animal and harvesting a set amount of animals using a specific weapon next to walking distance and time spent in the game. The points you build up here is basically your hunterscore that is used to progress you through levels from beginner to intermediate and further to elite. The higher the level, the bigger prizes in competitions too. Other than that it doesn't do much but placing you somewhere on a leaderboard.The graphics in the game is quite nice, though a little bit dated. The graphic engine used is the same that was used in Just Cause 2 I believe, with a few modifications. The reserves are rather huge and it will take you hours to walk from one side to another. There are 36 animals (soon 37) to hunt on 11 reserves as of november 2016. The reserves offer variations in terrain, animals, geography and seasons. Something for everyone in other words. The sounds of the animals and the weapons are also mostly well made with the occational time when you can clearly tell that it is a recording and a bit too loud when it rains. Speaking of weather. That is probably one of the things that is not technically good in this game. You wander around and you see sun and blue sky in every direction and then suddenly it starts to pour down like there's no tomorrow a second after. The weather effects in this game needs a big overhaul.Then there is of course a handful or two of small glitches and bugs that never seems to get fixed. Rarely gamebreaking but can be irritating non the less. Even more irritating when it seems the developer is too busy creating new things they can sell with "micro"transactions to do anything to fix what is broken. One has to take into account that it is a niche game and a small develop team basically working 9 to 5, so one can't expect too much. With the resources they have they have certainly made quite a game over the years and it is ever evolving, so there's that atleast.It is worth mentioning that the game has to have an online connection too, or you won't be able to play. If the server goes down so does your game. An unfortunate but nescessary evil in the game model they are running. Luckily it doesn't happen too often, but if it happens friday night you might likely have to wait to monday before they fix it, as it seems the devs have a monday to friday work schedule. Well, to end this rambling and finish this review:If you like a realistic simulator where you sneak, stalk and search for that one big animal to win you a competition and if you aren't worried about paying for your entertainment then you should definitely check out this game. It can be highly addictive, but relaxing. Slow, but thrilling. It is a game you might find yourself coming back to over and over again.However, if you are looking for free entertainment and a actionful game with a lot of running around then this is definitely not for you. You can walk around here for an hour without catching a glimpse of a single animal. Running scares the animals away as they can here you from a long  distance. It does not get much slower paced than this.You need patience in this game.If there was a neutral grading of this game I would probably neither rate it up or down, but seeing that I have had countless of entertaining hours in this game I feel I have to recommend it, even though it is definitely not for everyone and I would never ever EVER call it "Free-to-Play".Side note: You do not need to be a hunter in real life to enjoy this game. I have never in my life hunted or killed a single animal and probably never will. Pixelated animals however needs to watch out ;o)For what the game is, not looking at what it claims to be, I'd rate this game a 7/10Happy Gaming!

												*Just scroll down to the lower half of my review if you want proper Pros and Cons instead of a story*This game caught me off guard. I was bored one day, hopping from store page to store page of F2P games. All of them seeming like the same cash-grab garbage. So I stumble upon this game with it's Mostly Negative rating and assumed it was another cash-grab that needed to be purged.I downloaded it because I had been angered by the sheer amount of F2P cash grabs and decided I should throw a negative review at one of them.So I played this game for a bit. I enjoyed the game-play quite a bit actually, perhaps the only good hunting sim out there at the moment. Played without paying any money for a little over a week and was ready to post a nice little negative review. However, I noticed people that posted positive reviews did not seem like blind fan-boys trying to avoid regretting the money they put into the game.Noticed the monthly subscription fee was among the smallest I had ever seen ($3.33 per month) and there are 3 Starter packs of different prices that offer some items along with a few months of membership. So I decided "F*** it" and bought the Wayfarer Starter Pack.I eventually came to the conclusion that this game is pretty damn good with a low price. If you want to play this game without spending a dime then run fast and run far.The nice little "Free-to-Play" label next to Play Game isn't quite true. It should say "$14.99 | Add to Cart" and have "Download Demo" off to the side. So for the game:PROS:+ Slowpaced relaxing game-play.+ Many species of animal that require different methods to hunt. (Many share different styles while some are unique)+ Rather low-entry fee compared to other "Free-To-Play" games.+ Decent community. Only encountered one troll in multiplayer who was quickly banned by the admin.+ There is an in-game currency earned by completing missions which can be used to buy consumables and temporary licenses for non-members.+ Still supported and updated by the developers. The developers have also relaxed some of the restrictions for non-members, such as adding a free animal rotation and making all the reserves free.+ An actual hunting simulator with tracking, flushing, etc. Instead of those low-budget shooting galleries that are on store shelves.+ A huge variety of equipment to allow constant play-ability and variation.+ Low cost membership grants access to all animals to hunt. You start with a 12 Gauge shotgun which can be used to hunt every animal except for Bison.+ There is a wonderful satisfaction in going for a group hunt then taking a group selfies in front of the kill.+ Nice sound design.+ Looks decent without causing FPS drops on my potato rig.+ Servers are stable most of the time.CONS:- All equipment cost real money.- The "Earn EMS" system to gain money via methods other than directly paying does not work at all. I've taken enough surveys to earn over $100 in in-game currency and haven't received a dime.- Some animals are clearly added just to sell specific equipment. Bison require high-powered rifles, Black Bears are so skittish you almost always need a bait barrel and you cannot hunt ducks without buying a plethora of equipment to the point it feels like you purchased the "Duck Hunting" DLC. I personally haven't delved into most of the equipment yet so I cannot say if they're worth it or not yet.- Slow-paced gameplay is not for everyone.So far I have spent $60 on this game. 15 of which went into the Wayfarer starter pack.Overall I recommend this game IF you are willing to put some money in it. If you're open to putting money in it I recommend getting it for free and seeing if it is for you. If you are adamant about not spending a dime then stay away.

												I've got about 140hrs in this game before it came to steam, which gives a total of ~200.I have also spent over 100$ for in-game items and licences. I'm guessing the only reason why I played it for so much was the fact, that there aren't any other decent hunting games.Unfortunatelly I really can't recommend this game to any new players.First of all, it gets more and more outdated because engine is getting old and has plenty of limitations.Secondly, the game is not Free to Play at all. Free accounts have access to 2 terrible guns, one bad scope and can only hunt a few animal species. You might be able to spot a boar but you won't be able to shoot it. Frustrating.You have to buy licences to hunt all the animal species, and you can buy a licence for 3, 6 or 12 months. Yeah, it's a subscription fee, to play this game. And that's not everything.Then you learn about ethical weapons and the fact, that you need different weapons to hunt different species. Quickly you realise that you need to buy extra wepons and you can only do that with rl money.So you spend extra 50$ on a proper rifle with good scope, a revolver, pistol holster, a bow, a backpack to carry all that stuff, maybe some camo clothing or a fancy binocs with rangefinder.Now you can start to hunt and it's quite fun. For a while...Then you get to the same point I did. You have killed every single animal species, long range, short range, revolver kills, bow kills. What can I do next?Misssions. Missions reward you with in-game currency that can be used to buy mostly consumable items. Honestly, there is nothing usefull that you can buy for that. Forget about buying guns  or even callers.It gets worse. Many, many of the missions require you to use a specific weapon to complete them. You either spend rl money on some crappy gun (but I need it for a mission) or just ignore missions completly, since they are a waste of time.Then you move to competitions.Some competitions require specific guns but there should be plenty available where you can compete with any gun. To win a comp, usually you need to harvest a highest scoring animal. Most comps last 48hrs, some of them have limited attempts.Winning a comp gives you a trophy and some em$. That's the currency that is usually only purchaseable with rl money!You might think that this is solution to all your problems. Win enough comps and be able to afford guns and items.Sorry to disappoint you.Unless you are willing to spend countless hours, you won't win a thing. You might get lucky and bag a winning animal on your first attempt, but chances for that are extremly low. From my experience: winning a comp that wasn't even very popular (not many players competing) required around 12 hours of playing (6hrs a day).You will find out that most of the players, still playing this game, are massive no-lifers. MASSIVE.There are competitions that require you to bag as many animals as possible in 48hrs period of time. Regularly you will have players that are willing to spend up to 40hrs online in that period (forget about sleeping etc) just to win a reward that is worth 1-2$.Soon you will realise that you're better off paying 5$ for a new gun that spending 100hrs doing competitions.Eventually, there is no reason to keep playing this game. You got every animal, had some fun. Missions are pointless and a cashgrab attempt, competitions are for people with no jobs, who can pay 10+ hrs a day.

												This is the hunting simulator I've been wanting for years, and you can love it too, if you keep a few very important details in mind:1. Despite its claims, this game is not really free to play, or at least, the free to play model is not great. To really enjoy it you need to invest a good $30-$40 to get some good equipment (so you don't scare every animal away immediately) and licenses (so that you can hunt any animal). 2. This is NOT an arcade-type hunting game. It actually requires you to hunt, tracking your prey and occasionally losing them. It takes time and patience. There will not be ten bucks popping out at you every five seconds. This is actually what I love about the game, but I can see how some would not take to it as easily if they were expecting something else. Besides, the world is gorgeous. Take time to walk and enjoy the sights along the way. Pro tip: After the first 150 yards or so after leaving your hunting camp, don't use the run button. It can scare the animals away. Again. you have to be able to enjoy a slower-paced game.3. The user interface takes some getting used to. It doesn't work like your average first-person shooter, and there is not a great tutorial that teaches you everything. Most of your important items, like your weapon and deer call and such are mapped to the number keys. Watch a beginner's guide on Youtube or on the TheHunter wiki page before diving in.If you can handle those three things, you are in for an incredible hunting simulation. The slower-pace makes the successful kill incredibly satisfying, and the online tournaments you can enter (you don't play with other people; just submit your best kills to see who scores the highest) add tons of incentive to keep playing. As I said, part of the joy of this game is just enjoying the world. I don't know how many screen shots I've taken during my time in-game. It's beautiful. Happy hunting!Pros: Excellent hunting simulationBeautiful worldStellar sound qualityCons:Not really Free-to-PlayUser interface could be betterSome might not like the slower pace8.5/10

TL;DRF2P is a Demo-Mode only. Solid hunting game with detailed hunting grounds, cheap MMO-like payment model, rare but large actual content updates but loads of optional microtransaction material.F2P and Payment modelThe F2P content contains the license to hunt Whitetail Deer, Pheasant and three kinds of Rabbit only. As of the latest major Patch you now get a shotgun for free as well, so the grindwall for hunting the rabbits and pheasant is gone. One ingame currency "GMS" can be obtained by doing missions like "Track a Mule Deer", "Harvest a Mule Deer", "Spot a Whitetail Deer". Its a pretty useless currency though.The payment model lets you pay per month in order to get a license for all animals, so think of it as a "cheap MMO-type payment". However in contrast to MMOs, actual content updates to be played by you as a license holder appear only a few times a year. On the other hand these updates usually contain a new hunting reserve with new animals, so they offer quite some content.There are a lot of weekly minor updates with new guns, clothes and other equipment not really needed for playing the game though.The GameIn my opinion thehunter is a well-made hunting simulator with decent animal behavior and very well made highly detailed hunting reserves.The negative points I want to mention are random fps-drops in certain areas of the map which many players seem to encounter, "old animals" seem a bit lacking in texture quality compared to the new ones as well as "old reserves" are not as diverse and different from each other as the more recent ones. Some reserves are considered lackluster by a majority of the playerbase due to "recycling" of animals, e.g. the Australia reserve only contains the kangaroo as a specifically australian animal.Some content patches in the past caused problems for players to connect in multiplayer games.How much does it cost ?If there is no sale going I can not recommend buying a membership via the Ingame Store at all. Instead, I highly recommend to get the DVD Version of 2013 for ~10 € which is a far better deal.Basically this DVD Version comes with everything you need in contrast to the ingame-store sets. Even if you want to extend your membership, the DVDs offer much more. For some animals, callers are quite handy, so you might want to plan another ~10€ for callers. For fox and coyote I think the "Jackrabbit caller" is essential, for the rest of the callers you dont own it is really dependant on your playstyle. The same goes for any more "advanced" hunting clothing.To summarize, I think buying a DVD-Version which offers a fair deal, if you can not get the 2013 Version you will need ~5€ for a decent big-game hunting rifle, depending on the ongoing sales.Important:Do not buy any of the starter packs unless the largest one gets a hefty discount on Steam, because the other ones will leave you with the lack of a big-game rifle as well and are lackluster in value proposition compared to buying any DVD Version.One thing that should be mentioned here is goose and duck hunting. Though you can find those animals without any special equipment, you will need this equipment should you want to hunt birds in large scale.Since geese and ducks require dummies and a special hunting setup you need ~15 €, depending on the current sales for a goose or a duck setup, so these act as "DLCs".AlternativesMost of the "Cabelas" Hunting  games are just mass animals shooters, the "Cabelas Big Game Hunter Pro Hunts" is not bad though, just simplified mechanics.If you enjoy the detailed landscape and the "slow" gameplay, you might want to look into "Fishing Planet". This one actual is true F2P, but comes with a high grindwall.

This review mostly discusses the main issue the game has for most people – the pricing model. If you are looking for a gameplay or more balanced review, please Google for a “Let’s play” video or read another review instead. The positive recommendation only applies if you deem the pricing model as discussed acceptable.First things first - This title is not Free to Play.If you are looking for a free to play hunting title i have to start this review with some bad news: this game is not free to play by most interpretations of the term "Free to play". As a limited member you can do the following:  You can enter all the reserves and wander around. You receive one basic rifle, a scope and unlimited ammunition refills for that rifle. You will also receive a deer caller. You can only hunt Cottontail rabbits and Mule Deers. Hunting all other animals is prohibited in the sense that you cannot do so at all. You can see them, but shooting them is not possible.Unlike other free to play games you cannot feasibly unlock new content by playing the game a lot or by being good at it. You are stuck with what you have and that is it – and it’s admittedly not too much. The pricing model.So, you made it past the initial post explaining the game is not free to play and might be considering picking the game up? In that case, let us talk about the games pricing model and what it entails. The games pricing model is twofold: there are both subscriptions and items purchases. Subscription:  Subscription starts at 9.99 for a 3 month period which is arguably quite good compared to most MMO's. In exchange for your subscription you will receive unlimited ammunition for all the weapons you own, and a license to hunt all species of animals in the game. It is also possible to buy ammunition and animal hunting licenses as separate items though the monetary exchange rate for this is fairly bad in comparison. (But perhaps worthwhile if you are a very casual player)Items: Buyable items cover a broad range of possibilities. There is weapons, scopes, clothing, deployables (Hunting towers), utilities (Animal callers, storage increasing backpack) and temporally power-ups (Wind indicators, facial paint et cetera).Except for the power-ups all items are permanent once bought, with the caveat being that you will need an animal license and ammunition to hunt specific animals. There is an additional caveat as well: Each weapon can only be used on a subset of the animals in the game - you cannot use a pistol on a bear or a rifle on a pheasant for example. If you want to hunt all animals you will need to buy multiple weapons. The utilities sold are somewhat more optional though a huge convenience: callers enable you to coax animals them out of hiding or locate them, while specific clothing will provide superior camouflage thus fewer running animals as you try to sneak upon them.Bottom line? Expect to buy a membership and - depending on playing preference - one or more weapons, scopes and clothing if you wish to fully enjoy everything the game has to offer. The cheapest variety would be buying the wayfarer pack for about 15 Euro's; this includes 3 months of membership, a shotgun, a pistol with scope and some consumables. The shotgun itself is - with different ammo types - able to take down every type of animal in the game. Alternative you can do some research and find yourself a relatively cheap combination of items that allows you to hunt virtually everything the way you want it. Still, don't be surprised if you end up forking 20-30 bucks over initially if you chose this route (that figure includes a 3 month membership). Final thoughts.Despite the games price model arguably being steep I personally find myself enjoying the game quite a bit, so for me it is well worth the triple-a equivalent price I spend on it so far. Considering my current time invested, the subscription fee and my lack of a need to buy new items the game will be cheaper than a regular subscription MMO if I keep playing it another month or two, while spending a similar amount of time on it.That said: I can only advice the game to people who – like me – enjoy hunting simulations quite a bit. If you plan on picking up the game you should be able to live with the thought of having to possibly do a relatively sizable investment initially, followed by a fairly mild recurrent billing scheme. It is not a good pickup for people looking exclusively for a free to play title due to the rather sharp limitations and the inability to unlock content by playing a lot or being good. Still, the game itself is a lot of fun if you like hunting sims. If you can stomach the need for payment and don't mind doing some research into the items you want i can hearthily recomment it.Addendum - How to make the most out of your game without paying a dime: There is an excellent guide on the forums by Maverick that discusses the topic of getting the most out of the game without paying a dime for it. The method discussed will not grant access to all content indefinitely: You will be reliant on missions and counting your bullets. 												Let me just start off by stating that I’m giving a positive rating because I think TheHunter is a decent game, but despite this I’m going to get pretty negative in this review, mostly because it’s essentially one very long complaint of a problem that I think is crippling to the game. I’m also not going to summarize how the core game works at all, so if you’re looking for a review of that then this probably won’t help much.As you can probably already see from the Steam reviews, there’s been a lot of controversy about Thehunter’s Free 2 Play model. I never had much experience with this, as I started out paying for membership, but the controversy eventually led Expansive Worlds to revise their model to a slightly less intrusive one, but asides from the confirmation that is was indeed a pretty bad model I think that maybe a lot of the negative reviews are undeserved.In general I think that periodical charges are perfectly reasonable in a game which offers continuous updates and new content, and TheHunter is one of the better hunting games in a video game genre otherwise marred by some pretty embarrassing design standards. It should be pretty clear from my playtime here on Steam that I like it. Despite a visible need for polish in terms of the games UI design and how the game conveys important information, as well as a pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥decision to make everything including the launcher fully dependant on Expansive Worlds’ servers (which means that when there’s problems on their end you can’t play the game at all, not even singleplayer, and sometimes a host can lose connection to her or his own game). However, the main problem that I’ve chosen to write about in this review stems from how the ingame store operates.For all means and purposes, TheHunter is a stealth game where the primary goal is to kill animals. In a stealth game about killing things, what are some of the general design elements that are the most crucial to providing variety and thereby prolonged engagement, i.e. fun, to the experience? Well, having different environments to play in and having different ways to kill things.If you pay for membership, (or if you use in-game currency to buy permissions for hunting different animals) you’re provided with the rudimentary means to hunt all animals within all 10 different reserves, and the environments of the different reserves do impact the difficulty of the game and the way you have to play in order to hunt efficiently, so in that case the game fulfills the first of those requirements.There’s also a large variety of different weapons to use and different equipment to use, and they all impact the way you can hunt significantly. Some weapons are silent, some weapons are light, some weapons are powerful and heavy, and you can get hunting blinds, bait, camouflage clothing, dogs, bows, and all other sorts of cool stuff to hunt animals in different ways,-BUT ALL OF THAT COSTS MONEY.-Like most Free 2 Play multiplayer games with microtransactions, there’s two kinds of currency, gm$, earned by completing missions ingame, and em$, earned by paying for it with real money. What is different and ironically worse than the microtransactions of most other Free 2 Play multiplayer games is that the stuff which can actually be bought with gm$ is currently limited to only the absolutely most pitifully uninteresting consumables that the game has to offer;You cannot buy weapons with gm$. You cannot buy tents or hunting blinds with gm$. You cannot buy bait barrels, which are required to use bait, with gm$. You cannot buy dogs with gm$. You cannot buy clothing with gm$. You cannot buy scopes with gm$.Essentially, any digital items which are permanently added to your character, or which actually do something significant to the gameplay requires payments in addition to your membership subscription, which to me is much more significant assery than the notorious former Free 2 Play structure. The concept of having to buy ingame equipment in order to have fun in a game that you’re already supporting through periodical charges is ludicrous.TheHunters main equivalent of points in its semi-competitive community high-score system is HunterScore, which is rewarded for getting ingame milestone achievements, like “25 Mule Deer harvests” or “100 .243 bolt action rifle harvests”. There is a maximum limit to the HunterScore which can be achieved, but since getting there requires killing animals with all weapons in the game, including those which cost money, it effectively acts as a Pay 2 Win structure if you really want to spend the ridiculous amount of time it requires to actually compete with the top players.The problems of the cost structure are slightly alleviated by the retail packages, which in some areas are actually way cheaper and offer more value than just buying membership online. With my first retail package I felt that I was getting significantly more value for my money than the 14.99€ “Wayfarer” starter package I bought on Steam, and this led me to later buy a couple of other packages from a german website in order to get some more new equipment and some added membership time. This time it was far less of a satisfying purchase, though, partly because it was less cheap and partly because only the membership and the single “special edition” weapon I got from the packages was actually useful to me. Most equipment offered in the retail packages is the same as every other retail package, save for usually one “exclusive” premium item, usually a weapon.You can stack multiple pieces of the same equipment in TheHunter, but it seems like an oversight much more than anything else, because you can’t actually do anything with spare pieces of equipment. There’s no trading system, you can’t sell them for a bit of money, and there’s no point of having two of the same gun with you on a hunt since you’re limited to the same amount of ammunition as when you’re carrying one anyways. If anything they do make navigating your inventory more tedious, because you’ll eventually see, like, 6 .243 bolt action rifles and 6 12 gauge single shot shotguns because you’ve activated 5 different packages which all contained roughly the same guns and because there isn’t even any option to discard them. In fact, with one of the recent updates the 12 gauge single shot shotgun is now the only weapon in the store which costs 0 em$, so just for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles I bought 100 and now my ingame inventory is cluttered with them.Anyways, now that I got the retail packages from Germany and activated them, I haven’t really ended up feeling like I made a good purchase. Instead, I really feel like a gullible idiot, and probably rightfully so. It’s mostly this feeling which is the reason as to why I’m writing this review in the first place. The weapons in TheHunter are only digital trinkets after all, and I don’t think it’s right to spend money on digital trinkets like this in the first place. I don’t understand the need for it either, if it was possible to at least also buy weapons for gm$ in addition to em$, it would provide a major incentive for players to keep playing the game, and since membership requires a subscription already, then what’s the problem?Shouldn’t the membership subscriptions be paying for the maintenance and content updates of the game so that these seemingly kind of greedy and seemingly unnecessary micro transactions wouldn’t be needed? What’s the point of having two separate payment systems operating in the same game?I like the game, but looking at the store really just makes me annoyed. After the tremendous amount of negative reviews following the former Free 2 Play model, though, they did revise it in the end. Maybe one of the next priorities could be revising the payment system?

												Ok then - theHunter. It's rivalling in terms of hours played my other big favourite of the moment, DayZ, and I'd like to tell you why.Firstly I am a real life hunter and shooter, but living in the UK access to real weapons and hunting isn't always easy. So when I saw this game for free, I thought it's worth giving a go. I haven't seen another game in this niche for 10 years, so I was keen to see what it offers.I'm going to deal with the free to play issue. This game can be played for free. You can access all areas of the reserves straight away, and beautiful they are. Yes you are given two weapons for ffree - a scoped .243 and a 12 bore shotgun, but these two weapons are good for all but one species on the many reserves you can hunt on, and have limitless ammo. In terms of what you can hunt, you are restricted to one species of deer to start with but can also hunt three variants of rabbits plus pheasants for free. Additionally you will get two extra species free to hunt every week on a rotating basisYes there is downloadable content to buy - if you want to - but it's not at all necessary for the enjoyment of the game. I compare it to a well known MMO tank game; you can do it all for free if you want and earn your way to stuff in game play or you can add real money and do it quicker and funner. TheHunter's the same - it gives you the option to use real money if you really want to.Pricing if you want to use real cash? Well it's minimal. Yes there is the option to buy a membership which for me is 8 English pence a day giving me licenses for all animals on the reserves plus free reloads of ammo. In terms of £ spent to hours played, as I have bought some extras, I'm on about £40 for over 200 hours, and I can see the hours going up and the £ spent staying at about £40. Considering I was charged £1 to aprk for 30 minutes today in town, I don't find this bad value for money at all.Game play and graphics are ok - I do find it very immersive with TrackIR and Dolby 7.1 headphones. 60fps at highest graphic settings doesn't strain my middle of the road desk top PC.What makes this game a challenge is that stalking and fieldcraft are probably more important than the shooting element. This is not some sort of immersive shooting gallery. Game can be elusive, wary, spookable, and even dangerous. If all you require is a game to blast holes in things try Sniper Elite.The only downside for me is that the designers have had to make some gameplay approximations and simplifications which make the game less realistic, and less of a challenge. The most notable one for me is that the rifle trajectories are effectively flat, and range finding isn't really part of the game as your encounter ranges tend to be well under 50 metres. There's no wind effect on the shot either, so real life skills of range finding, usind hold over for range, and allowing for the wind don't appear here which is a shame.Game play summary: you will spend a lot of time walking slowly from cover to cover straining your ears and eyes for the signs of animals which you can then track and if you get it right you will eventually see them and get in a position to shoot. A critic called it a walking simulator - sounds like he was a poor hunter as stealth is the key.So thinking of trying it? Well all you have to lose is the download time to your disc. If you like the first couple of hours you'll probably decide to splash a little cash for a basic membership to give you quicker access to hunting species other than the free mule deer.I've seen a review below where someone makes out that if you want to play the game you need to buy this and buy that and the sums run into large amounts of $. It's not so. You do not need to buy every bit of kit in the game - one shotgun with its birdshot, buckshot and solid slug will let you take on every single species on the map.So that's it for me. It is a good hunting simulator. There is Gucci gear available for real £ but you can do a lot with a very little £. You can do massive amounts with no £ at all as long as you accept: a) you need to work your way up the game to earn in game currency b) you need to use the right skills to do this - play like a CoD buffoon and you'll never succeed c) that people with real £ can buy goodies if they want to without stopping the game being free to play d) that there is no 'win' in this game other than the satisfaction you get from hunting with skill

The rating on the review is because of immature idiots who want everything for free - got nothing to do with the game. If you're a spoiled immature brat wanting more handouts to go with your welfare cheque, mark it down and ♥♥♥♥ off. Don't bother with entitlement whining in the comments, I'll just kill it...oo00oo..Now, the game.- GRAPHICS -This is gorgeous. A 6.00am start at Redfeather had me mesmerised. There are some placing issues, grass and trees above ground etc. but it's really only aesthetics and does little to detract gameplay. With my trusty 670gtx/i7/8Gb rig this game shines with only minor fan speedup when scene changing. A steady 60fps with only minor tearing (I haven't bothered changing the default yet so could probably be sorted easily enough).Very easy to look at and the animalation (now there's a word) is very attractive. Slightly robotic at times but hey, if we had 500,000 vectors to plot per animal we couldn't play without a Cray.- SOUND -There could be a little more control over some of the ambients, eg: ocean waves, as sound is a critcal and tactile sense in this game and some of it gets over the top. Rain, wind etc. is good and animal calls, while lacking in some bearing seperation, is true to form.And the guns? Wow. Crank it people. It might take 2 hours of tracking before you fire but I get great delight hearing the .308 reverb off the valley walls. My kids, avid fans all, bounce off their chair! The bang-ratchet-bang of the pump action while pheasant shooting is as sweet as.(Err.... an 11.00pm .308 shot scored me some wife-wrath so headphones people!)- GAMEPLAY -If holding shift + W is your only way to get somewhere this is NOT your thing. If the destination is more important than the journey or you're expecting a gluttony of "shootables", DO NOT BUY.This requires patience and lots of it, much of it is tedium. This is hunting. You are a hunter. Stealth. Cover. Shadows. Crouching. Camoflauge. Downwind. ALL of this comes into play.  I've even suggested on the forums that you need to move like YOU are the hunted for best results. Animals, particularly those munched on by predators have an uncanny sense of smell and hearing. And it IS fascinating to watch animals through a scope pausing, sniffing and treading lightly. "Wary skittishness" has been modelled beautifully and really adds to the sense of the hunters plight... Let's face it, we're blundering lunkheads in natures true arena and you'll pay the price for it.-Shooting. In RL, I have probably loosed close to 10,000 rounds. Mostly night shooting for foxes and roos. As a staunch user of the .243 in that era I took great delight in how well this acts, sounds and plays like a .243 ingame. I can "feel" the shoulder kick and smell the powder. (I know, it's psychosomatic but you get what I'm saying....)Scope tracking is well mimiced and looking downrange for a headshot @ 150m is frustratingly difficult. Zoom capabilities are also true-to-form in that higher zoom will produce greater scope movement. Nice work in this department. Note that there are many scopes, sizes and types, many aimed (yck yck) at quality shooting and range judgement.- The shotty is divine albeit a rather blunt instrument. - The .30 is popular and goes off like a firecracker on steroids.- The Anshutz .308 -a spend money on it- gun has just entered my inventory and is a darling to use. I linked it up with a 9x50 and I'm REALLY loving this outfit.I've made mention on the forums that I'm concerned that there is no score rewards based on target range despite the obvious (monetary) push to high-quality equipment. In my view this is wrong, both ingame and economically. My weapons and equipment need to be valuable to me but there is no reason to use anything other than a 12 gauge with the right ammo for the kill. Why charge up to $15 RL money for a gun and scope that counts towards.... nothing?-Animal TrackingI like the way this has been done. It's very difficult to mimic the senses from a 3D enviroment in a 2D rectangle and yet this gives a sense of tracking success with target sighting as the eventual reward. The kill itself does become secondary on the harder to track species and I've once or twice found myself shooting only a photo and simply walking away. Seriously.-CompetitionsGood fun and ultimately (at least for me) is the reason I play. Nope, I haven't won any as I write but I've got close. The planning and dedication required to win a trophy is high level stuff and really needs to be worked at. I'm loving them. Soon.......- GENERAL -In the interests of brevity I'm going to mention the words achievements (LOTS of them), missions, multiplayer, XP building all in the one sentence. The reasons will be quite obvious. You gotta pay to play, not a real lot, and it's worth every cent.- UI - In a sentence on the launcher windows. Messy. Clunky. Confusing. EW. Get someone on this. Rule of thumb, evaluate your UI on your grandmothers. If they're confused it's bad OK?  Even ingame I find some "habit formed clicking" breaks on some changes to equipment. ..oo00oo..- SUMMARY -CONSTedious at times with all that walking.Could ultimately cost quite a bit.UI.Scoring is errr.... pointless. (pun intended)As an Aussie, I find it filled with Americanised hunting claptrap and hyperbole. Less Greenpeace and more hunting is needed, it's a GAME :)PROSAwesome sound/graphics on good/high-end systems.Great immersion and true-to-life animals and in particular their behaviour.Good choice of weaponry and associated peripheral match-ups.Provides a very real sense of hunting.If you're an RL hunter but can't get out enough. GET THIS. No question.9/10 (amended score and review*)gg*Amended review to reflect continued use. 1000+ hours now and still immersed. Heavily. :)

												This is a somewhat lengthy review, so if you're looking for a simple answer, this game may not be for you, or you may want to look at other reviews. Let's be super clear about what this game is, and what it isn't:What it is:1) The most realistic hunting experience to date (IMO).2) Offers a plethora of options, weapons, locales, and equipment.3) Beautiful, even by today's standards. It's starting to show it's age, but still has wonderfully beautiful moments.4) Content is updated weekly, with new equipment, animals, new locations, etc., added regularly as well.5) Enjoyable, with patience. The game mostly calms me.6) Offers a fun multiplayer experience, including competitions and cooperative play.7) A free game, that allows you to hunt some species, and are given a few weapons to help you get along. There are weekly rotations on animals that non-members can hunt.8) A membership service for a larger experience.9) The free version is essentially a demo.What it isn't:1) A game that allows you to hunt everything, with all the equipment, etc., without spending money.2) A pay to win game. Winning is only in the eye of the beholder. You're generally only competing with yourself.3) A game with a low learning curve.4) Perfect.I've put over 500 hours into this game, and likely a few more hundred if you include my time spent in the game prior to transferring it to Steam. I feel as though I might have a complete view of this game, flaws and all. This game certainly has it's flaws, some of which stem from it using an older gaming engine, some of which stem from a team switch (probably some legacy code), and some of which stems from a misunderstanding of the payment model. Simply put, when you get this game for free, you're given a limited amount of items and weapons, and can only hunt a limited amount of species. To some, this may seem like a pay to win game, but there is no "end-game," and "winning" is subjective at best. About being a new player, this game requires an investement of time. First, you have to learn what the game is trying to teach you (there's plenty of tutorials, videos, etc., available to help you understand some of this). The developers sometimes keep rather quiet about certain aspects of the game, such as where animals spawn, etc., but this is purposely done to keep you guessing, and never 100% sure about the mechanics of the game. This keeps the game lively, and allows you to learn from others. Many of my conversations with other players center around the best spots for hunting, and other unknowns, with a large amount of incorrect information. I don't mind this, because as I said, it keeps the game interesting, and even after this many hours, I'm still learning.Seeing the game advertised as free, then realizing you can't hunt everything in the game can put a lot of people off. I place blame on the way the game is marketed, but if you enjoy hunting game experiences, don't let this put you off. You do NOT need a membership to enjoy the game, although you're going to be limited to a few species, and two species that are rotated weekly. You get free ammo for the weapons you get as a non-member. You can hunt on any reserve, but are limited in the species you can legally hunt. In order to unlock the game fully, you must get yourself a membership. Alternatively, you can purchase licenses as a non-member to hunt specific species. If you purchase a firearm, you will have to purchase ammo for it. As I said, this can be daunting, and put new players off. Let's talk about memberships. A basic membership allows you to hunt all species, on all reserves, for a period of time. This will also allow you to get free replenishment on ammo for all weapons you own. Some memberships last for up to a year, which means if you pay into this game, you'll eventually be paying to upkeep your membership (I pay about $30 a year my membership). Some memberships come with equipment, which help you get started, and are cheaper than trying to buy the equipment indivudually. Once you have purchased equipment (via membership or otherwise), you always keep it. Some of the equipment is centered on equipment bundles for species, such as ducks, etc. It's up to the user to decide which membership they want. Let's talk about equipment. As a new member, you're given some basics, which is helpful for most deer species. You're give a rifle and a shotgun, which allows you to hunt anything in rotation or that comes with a non-member. Should you upgrade, the weapons you have allow you to hunt everything except one or two animals species. Everything else in this game is entirely optional. Many of the firearms are redundant (same weapon, different or unique skins). Some weapons are better for certain types of species, such as the .22 (useful for rabbits, geese, etc.), while others such as the .370 are excellent for very large game. There are decoys, dogs, blinds, stands, and all sorts of items that can be optionally used in your hunts. Some of this equipment makes it easier to hunt a particular species, such as a duck caller, and a blind, but they are not essential to getting them. These items cost money. Again, this can be daunting for new players, because there are so many species, and so many items. Certain memberships provide you with everything you need to hunt the vast majority of species with ease. If you were, however, to buy everything in the game, especially if it's not on sale or in a bundle, you're going to drop a huge amount of money (perhaps upwards of a thousand U.S. dollars or more).Buying items should only be done in the long term, when you realize your issues in hunting specific species. It requires you to invest some time, and to educate yourself so you get the best bang for your buck. It's part of the reason why this game has a high learning curve. In this way it mimics real life to some extent. You wouldn't use a bleat deer caller, for example, to call a moose. Throwing money at the issue won't assist you in becoming a better hunter, but time and patience will. Spend your money wisely, if you choose to spend money.When I first purchased a membership with this game, it was prior to Steam, but there was only one map, and a limited number of weapons. For me, over the years, I have been able to attain everything simply because it's within my gaming budget. I spend less on this game than what I would spend on buying other games during a month, and it keeps me coming back because of the high diversity, skill, and serenity the game provides. If you're someone going after achievements, you may be frustrated, and I would say this game isn't for you. As I said, this is about the long term. If, however, you have a lot of patience, and are looking for a deep hunting game experience, I highly recommend this game. There is just simply nothing else out there that can do what this game does.

Because, I was just like you (The Reader) at the start of it all, and also just like you (The Reader) my reaction to this game, the reviews and the Pay to Play factor just drove me away from this game COMPLETELY. When in the end, all that was needed to enjoy this game to full, was $49.99. How is that for Pay to Play??Okay, now for the actuall review.I will go as far as to say that this is the best hunting sim I have ever played, even though I was sceptical at the start because of the whole Pay to Play aspect of the game. At the time I HATED this game because it was Free to Play, but I cant even shoot anything in the game, because everytime I want to shoot, it tells me I need a license for this and license for that. I just got mad, and at the moment I felt like this game is the biggest pile of crap I have EVER played. Who even plays a crap game like this AND pours money into it?? What is this, another World of Warcraft??Till one day, I just felt like wasting money, and decided to waste money onto this game, because why not?? I went to the store page of this game's Launcher, and I went to purchase a Membership. Looking at the options I had, I decided to go with the Trailrunner Subscription ($49.99), which gives me a 12 month (Year) Membership to shoot what I want, where I want AND to ease me into the game, I got 9 extra Weapons to start off my game AND 35 other items to accompany me. Ranging from scopes for my 9 Weapons, Cammo, Lures, Backpack and much more usefull items. Eager to start out the game AND still keeping in mind that there is still MUCH MORE to purchase in the game store than what I got with my Subscription, I started a new game, and made due with what I had for the time being. The game started up and the hunt was on. With my lure at hand and my trusty .300 (Gotten from Trailrunner Subscription) I was determine to shoot some Deer.I set out with my trusty HunterMate, and I started learning the game and what goes for what. My first encounter was a Turkey. I went to the location of the Turkey call, and saw the tracks. My HunterMate told me in which direction the Turkey has fled, and I just follow along the path. The path led me through the Forest and Swampland areas, and I was soon greated with a Deer Grunt Call in the distance. It was at that moment I paused in my tracks. I took a crouching position, I got my Lure ready, and I called the Deer in. Sitting in the bush, looking left and right past the trees, through the bushes I am trying to find the Deer AND be as quite and low profile as I can get .... at the same time worrying about a stupid Turkey ....I saw the Deer peeking he's head over the scrubs infront of me, I bring up my .300 to scope .... I line up my shot and I just let it go. The Deer fell on the spot and I jumped with joy. I went to collect the Deer and I was happy with what I got. I went back to the tracks of the Turkey, and continued my journey.Its been a year later, and what was once a piece of crap game to waste money on, is now the best game I ever wasted money on. Funny how that works right?? Its also been a year later, and I only spend $49.99 on this game since then. Yes, you read that right. After one whole year, the Trailrunner Subscription for $49.99 was AND is all you need to enjoy this game to the fullest. I now renewed my Subscription for another year which is now $34.99. I used the other $15 and I bought myself more Lures to use on for the other animals, and I still only use my weapons and equipment I got from my Trailrunner pack. NEVER bought anything extra than what I got for spending $49.99 on this game.If you have sticked with me up until now in my review, I am sure you are now more convinced to actually try this game out INSTEAD of just looking at the Pay to Play factor and relying on the Review System of Steam.In general, all you EVER need to play this game is the Trailrunner Subscription. NOTHING more and NOTHING less. The other items you can purchase is just for better convinience and a better overall gameplay to make your life easier. In truth, the Weapons and Items you get in the Trailrunner Subsciption is MORE than enough to play this game to fullest of experience.Pros.1. Great Gameplay2. Great Hunting Sim3. A lot of Game Reserves to choose from4. Each Game Reserve has its own Game and Hunting tactics to adapt5. Overall very good hunting experience6. New Game Reserves was added (with Game) and is still being added (with Game)7. The game offers a level up system for each Weapon and Animal the more you use your Weapon and Track an Animal8. The game offers multiplayer where you can hunt with your friendsCons.1. Game engine is a bit out dated2. Devs does not seem to listen to its already small community to improve on overall user experience3. The controlls are kind of clunky and stiff, but you get use to itPutting it all together to sum it up. Purchase the Trailrunner Subscription ($49.99) and try this game out for yourself. Do NOT purchase the other subscriptions as you will not enjoy the game to the fullest, and they dont offer you as much gain as the Trailrunner Subscription does. Thats all you will EVER spend on this game in your life, and as you play the game, you will soon relise that you gave the game a unnecessary hard time BECAUSE of the overall Steam Review AND the fact that it is Pay to Play.Thank you for sticking with me the whole time through my review, if I helped you out, dont forget to click "YES" on "Was this review helpfull". And put your own positive review on this page.
